By D. H. WARREN
They'll tell you America has
come a long way.Through the red
scares, locking up
J apanese-Americans, Joseph
McCarthy, the violence of racism,
right down to Richard Nixon
they say the system works, and
by golly, you should be proud.
They'll also tell you that
Americans are good, decent
People, a moral, likeable lot.
They call the American working
man the finest, and also the best
taken care of. Even our
Paperboys make more than half
the people on this planet. For all
this, they say you should give
thanks.
The National Association for
the Advancement of Colored
People (NAACP) isn't giving
much thanks these days, or even
applauding the country to which,
for the last 70 years, they've
tried to bring justice. The
NAACP says they're running
scared, because the organization
has to come Lip with $1.5 million
by September 28 in order to
appeal a decision rendered in
Mississippi state court.
It sounds scary— (and it is).
Injustice comes to mind.(But are
legal justice and ethical justice in
this country necessarily
s Ynonymous?) Mississippi
completes the well-worn picture
You've painted in your head. The
Scenario that must come down:
Pat, illiterate rednecks donning
their hoods, putting nigrahs in
their place down South. South.
(They shoot easy riders, don't
they?)
Extremes
An accurate picture in this
case, as in most, lies somewhere
between the two extreme
versions of reality presented by
the adversaries. Merchants are
scrambling for dollahs on one
Side, the NAACP, their lives on
the other. The situation could be
called desperate, perhaps for
both parties involved; possibly
for ourselyks, as well.
the story is about a small
American town with a
Population of approximately
1 1,000, seventy-five per cent of
Whom are black. It is the City of
Port Gibson, in Claiborne
County, Mississippi.
Mississippi in 1966 was
beginning to feel the
repercussions of the 1965 Civil
Rights Act. Black citizens, aided
by Federal officials, began to
Push for equal treatment under
the law and the right to fully
Participate in the elective
Process. As with most • change,
there was resistance.
In Claiborne County, the local
chapter of the NAACP saw fit to
write a letter to the County
officials asking that the police
force, school board, and other
Public jobs he integrated. After
all, the town is three-quarters
black, with blacks having a voting
majority. Three months went by,
and "as public officials
sometimes do," no response was
given to the letter from the
NAACP. Another letter was sent,
this time with the added threat
of economic boycotts against
local white merchants. The

Association demanded that the
merchants hire black employees
and treat them fairly.
Dickson Pyles, attorney for
the plaintiffs in the case against
the NAACP, contends that the
Port Gibson businesses were
small, family affairs, and
therefore could not use outside
help. Emmet Burns, Director of
the Jackson NAACP, argues that
if this was so, why are these
places now hiring blacks? The
two sides tell different tales.
The boycott of the Port
Gibson merchants went on for
about a year. What happened
then is difficult to reconstruct.
The NAACP contends some
white merchants hired black
employees, prompting the end of
the boycott. Dickson Pyles says,
"It is difficult to determine, but
it seems they (the boycotters)
just got tired." He alleges some
merchants had black friends who
got the boycott ended for them.
This might be true, or it might
only be a story to add more
confirmation by circumstance to
the lawyer's case.
Shootings
In April 1969, the shooting of
a black man by a white
policeman rekindled the boycott,
bringing into focus the issue of
race. How and why Roosevelt
"Dusty" Jackson died is the
subject of contrasting opinions.
Emmet Burns tells us that
Jackson, one night in town,came
to the aid of a friend who was
drunk and about to be
incarcerated. Jackson asked the
policeman for permission to take
the man home. The officer
refused and threatened Jackson
with arrest. Later, "Dusty" was
shot at his home by the white
policeman. Charles Evers, mayor
of Fayette, Mississippi, claims
Jackson was shot with his hands
held.
The official police story says
that when the officer arrived to
arrest Jackson for interference
with justice, "Dusty" drew and
the trooper responded in
self-defense. The black man was
killed in the "scuffle."
At this point the stories really
begin to diverge.
Emmet Burns, who admits not
being in the city at that time,
says that the police told members

of the black community to wait
at the Baptist Church to be
informed about what had
happened to "Dusty" Jackson.
The townspeople were aware
something had happened, but
just what was still unclear. Bums
told the News-Letter that
sheriff's deputies fired into the
Church an hour later. Dickson
Pyles does not mention the
Church incident in his version of
the story, but does say that a
black man was shot by a white
police officer.
There is not a single article to
be found in the periodical
literature of the time about any
such shooting in Mississippi. No
record of anything like it could
be found in the files of the
Clarion-Ledger in Jackson,
Mississippi. An Associated Press
reporter, Ron Harrist, who was in
Port Gibson when the tragic
events of 1969 took place, was
unable to recall any act of
violence so outstanding as
pumping a Baptist Church full of
bullets.
Harrist reports that after the
shooting of "Dusty" Jackson,
Charles Evers, and state NAACP
President Aaron Henry organized
marches and demonstrations. A
curfew was imposed by the
county and state troopers were
brought in to enforce it. Harrist
recalls arrests being made for
curfew violations, but not for
acts of violence.
There was a large meeting at
the Baptist Church one night,
Harrist said, which he attended.
Rumors were going around that
the White were on the roof with
weapons, waiting for the blacks
to come out. Later, the whites
would circulate stories about
large amounts of guns found in
the Church.
Nobody, as far as Ron Harrist
knows, shot anybody that night.
In the wake of shooting, the
NAACP resumed their demands
for Black personnel in the Port
Gibson police department. When
this was tagain refused, the
boycott was reinstated, and
fortified by blacks opening
business cooperatives of their
own.
Dickson Pyles claims the
NAACP was able to keep the
boycott going by instituting a
"reign of terror" against those

blacks who would not cooperate.
In his eighty-four page opinion
on the case against the NAACP,
Judge George Haynes concluded
that such violence did occur. The
NAACP flatly denies the charges.
Ron Harrist syas he knew
nothing about a terrorizing
campaign by the NAACP. He had
observed spontaneous
confrontations between black
neighbors who fell on different
sides of the issue, but felt there
had been no organization,behind
any,of it.
Back in 1968, the state of
Mississippi passed a law against
secondary boycotts, admittedly
directed at the NAACP. With the
passage of the law , the
merchants of Port Gibson filed
suit against the • NAACP in
October 1969.
The Association received a
Federal injuntion to hold off the
suit, but several counter
injunctions and four years later
the case did come to trial. The
event lasted eight months. The
judge deliberated for three years.
The NAACP was found in
violation of not only the 1968
state law prohibiting secondary
boycotts, but also statutes
concerning monopolies and
trusts, Mississippi common law
for "interfering with a business
relationship," and guilty of
conspiracy for those things.
Dickson Pyles said that all of
the defendants took the stand
and admitted that they were
boycotting the merchants in
order to have their demands with
the government met. To Pyles, it
was a "classic secondary
boycott." Dickson Pyles is a
lawyer who has built his
reputation from his handling of
labor and civil rights cases. In the
1950's, Pyles had his office
bombed because of his
association with a civil rights
case. Dickson Pyles was hired by
the merchants because of his
extensive knowledge of boycotts.
The sum of $1.2 million was
arrived at by trying to determine
what might have happened to the
businesses if the boycott had
never occurred. Dr. Paul T.
Oliver, Mississippi University
economist, projected a trend line
to ascertain the extent of this
economic possibility. Dickson
Pyles said,"It took us two weeks

'genous to the South The cities and
towns of Mississippi and Alabama
have become the stage for the
nation's morality plays, because
it's all right to lynch the South.
Not that the South is any less an
offender 'than the North, East or
West. The nation is filled with
racism, but nobody wants to say
so. The great civil rights
movements have passed. Our laws
have been reformed. But can
people's feelings be legislated?
The NAACP is asking for help
right now to raise the funds they
need to appeal their case.
Legally, no injustice can be
claimed. The NAACP broke the
law and that's the way it goes.
Ethically, however, it could be
argued that the Mississippi laws
the Association violated are
unconstitutional and detrimental
to the welfare of the people of
that state and this country. More
importantly, what does it mean if
the NAACP gets put out of
business?
Certainly, the NAACP by
working for civil rights in a
country with a white majority,
has done much for people of all
colors. The Association, unlike
many other black organizations,
has historical been bi-racially
supported and drawn its
leadership from whites as well as
blacks
A little social conscience here
must go a long way. The , NAACP
is worth saving, not simply
because it is the NAACP but also
because if it does go, it could
mean the beginning of giant steps
backwards in terms of civil rights
in this country.
The Office of the Chaplain has
put out an urgent call for
volunteers to help with this
cause. Especially needed, are
students to speak to local
churches Sunday morning.
Training will be given on S
aturday, and interested persons
should call extension 8187.
A mass rally to express
support for the 1NAACP is
scheduled for Sunday,
September 26 at 8:00 p.m. at
the Prince Hall Mlsonic Temple,
Eutaw Place.
1307
Your contributions are tax
deductible. Your incentive
should be something more
important than that. How about
a free and 'fair America? How
about a free and clear
conscience?

Spotting the first Moonies

come out to see the graciously
respectful Moonies, free of any
signs of mental nullity or forceful
dogmatism.
Around the Monument, local
families had settled in for the
day, bringing their blankets,lawn

required some close analysis. A
couple playing flutes for
passers-by on the sidewalk turned
out to be mrerely a happy pair.
Strangers who mannered .
"hello" on that sunny afternoon
were suspect.
The suspense quickly
disappeared on Constitution
Avenue. Three young men seated
on a bench, the outer two
wearing identical brown suits, the
inner in white, all with blue
banners draped across the chest
proclaiming "God Bless
America." Their hair neatly
trimmed, indistinguishable in the
ill-fitting suits, they resembled
any other Capitol Hill aides,
except for their totally vapid
expressions. The proverbial blank
eyes for once became reality.
On approaching the Mall area,
the last choruses of the "Battle
Hymn of the Republic" drifted
into the city. After the song's
end, relative silence. No cheering,
no crowds backed up for five
blocks, no advance notices from
far-flung Moon promoters. The
strategy, considering the media
campaign centered on a low-key,
sott-sen approach. Let the people

chairs, boxes of Kentucky Fried
Chicken, and diversions for the
kids. The prospect of a Saturday
picnic, replete with Sunday radio
gospel music and a spectacular
fireworks exhibition, drew
thousands who were willing to sit
through an hour of some
self-proclaimed disciple babbling
in Korean about America's
tribulations. Coming from D.C.
they didn't need to hear about
false promises, foreign threats, or
ultimate salvation. A free, sunny
afternoon and colorful
evening—does it matter who
provides the entertainment?
Out of the crowd estimated at
25,000, then, more than half had
no connection with Moon, and
had no intentions of getting
involved. Kids ran around the
Mall waving flags and holding
posters, only as another game to
be played with available
equipment. Thousands of others
came out of curiosity, came for a
peek at these religious cyphers.
That left the actual number of
Moonies to a relatively small
amount. Hundreds of the
brown-suited young troops,
maybe two thousand delegates

from around the country. Not
very impressive for a cult
sweeping the nation and the
world.
Those followers did make a
Considerable impression, however.
Red-bannered Moonies patrolled
the immediate Monument area,
Picking up litter. The blue stripes
kept the aisles open as the crowd
Pushed toward the stage. Workers
in white jumpsuits with
the
insignia America the Beautiful on
their backs handled the
equipment for performers. Moon
hadn't forgotten the values of
military organization he had
Picked up in Korea.
The stage, positioned at the
foot of the Reflecting Pool,
Sported World Series bunting and
the flags and symbols of the U.
S.
and the Unification Church.
Behind the stage, the pool waters
swirled in a dismal grey, and the
Lincoln Memorial closed off, sat
in spotlit emptiness. Lincoln
could be imagined looking out
toward the insanity that paraded
in front of him, his American
dream come to a foreign voice
captivating the pioneering mind.
In front of the stage, a
fenced-in area extending thirty
yards back held the hard- core
i mportant Moonies. Foreign flags
displayed the world appeal; most
delegates, though, were D. C.
residents
invited for international
flavor. Beyond the fence,
national representatives held
sway over sections like a political.
convention. The travellers hardly
accounted for the whole country;
large delegations from New York,
Delaware, and Pittsburgh were
the extent of the yellow-post
standard bearers.
The entertainment for the day
got marginal interest from the
crowd, whether Moonies or
Picnickers. Only so many verses
41. "Oh, Happy Day" and "This
Is My
Country" can hold the
attention.
While East Met West
,during the Korean Folk Ballet's
"Drum Dance of Freedom,"
da shiki -clad hawkers peddled
i ncense to the hopefully
°riental-inspired crowd, and
Parents moaned, "I just wonder
how the hell we're going to get
Out of here in the dark."
Sit down
As Moon's stage time
a pproached, the crowd pushed
forward,
mostly for better seats
in anticipation of the fireworks
display to follow. Moonie in a
A
1950's V-neck sweater and
straight black pants pleaded,
'b rothers
and sisters, please sit
down,' as
the folks in front
strained to see this Sun Moon
characte r
.
Moon arrived promptly at
seven, as scheduled, flashing a
su
spiciously Nixon-like victory
slaute. The band and chorus
behind him, men dressed in
rev olutionary coats and
tri-cornered hats, the women in
Cowgirl floppy-hat white dresses,
Played and sang under the
Persuasive direction of a bouncy
naval band leader.
Moonies passed out tiny
Plastic American flags, the
sPeaker invoking the crowd "to
wave them when you feel the
sPirit." "We want a sea of flags."

maintained the same expression
they had plastered on them since
the first day of rebirth. Brown
suits, blue banners, and a shock
of blond hair topping an
ultimately stupid smile.
I +mak

Sure enough, Moon's presence
provoked a thirty-second
outburst of flag-waving,
sign-flapping ("One Nation
Under God," "N.Y. Loves Rev.
Moon"), and polite cheering. A
noticeable chorus of boos,
however, disrupted this
respectable show of enthusiasm.
The land of the Yippies. Black
flag waving with a marijuana leaf
centered on a red star. A small,
vocal knot of fifty Yippies
provided the camera crew on the
press platform a little 11:00
action. Not the Yippies of old,
though; more a collection of
high-school rowdies and
confirmed jokers. Confined to a
space in the crowd, they lacked
any original run-around antics.
Harmless comments were
traded between the Yippies and
their adversaries. "Sieg Heil" and
"Moon Go Blow" received
"Communist," "Satanist," and
"You ought to be exorcised" in
return. Moonies unfortunate
enough to be posted near the
Yippie enclave held
handkerchiefs over their mouths
to prevent the inhalation of
marijuana. The Park police, of
course, stayed away from the
band and dope smoking rather
than cause an ugly brawl.
Rah rah
The interplay between the
Yippies and Moonies turned into
an instant replay of high-school
football. Visitors rooting for the
opposing team made more noise
and sarcastic comments, while
the strength of home rooters
drowned them out at key
moments. Tying both sides
together was the aura of a loser.
For the Yippies (again not a
true claim to the title), their
members came for a one-shot
deal of getting high and being
crazy in front of a lot of people.

The Moonies uniformly had a
shallow protective g)A.7e; they
obviously didn't fit into a loose
unformed seventies spirit. To
believe in Moon seemed an easy
out. Just follow orders and smile
at all fortunes; believe in God
and the goodness of his creation
To be a Moonie meant escape
from the frustrations of life.
Simple answers."What does your
symbol indicate?" "The twelve
parts of humanity: love, thought.

interpreter went hoarse in the
middle of the address, spitting
out words like a frenzied debater.
Phrases such as "America must
wake up today—tomorrow may
be too late," "America will never
die, never, never, never!", and
"this will be the kingdom of God
on Earth" aroused only the
fenced-in delegates.
Back in the crowd, spectators
impatient for fireworks chatted
in mock Korean and downed

prayer, etc." "Why are there
guards every twenty feet along
this fence?" "So nobody gets
in." Sun Moon has arrived to put
the world in order, finish Christ's
work on earth.
Moon on stage lacked the Billy
Graham or Oral Roberts appeal.
No cripples discarding their
crutches and walking away. For
one thing, he spoke in Korean, a
difficult way to arouse
Americans to a pious pitch. His

around to outdo the Yippies.
Moon's departure, his last
appearance in this country, got a
restless twenty seconds of cheers,
the band striking up "God Bless
America," thousands of 'balloons
released into the air, and
searchlights outlining the
convention colors floating to the
Monument.
With Moon gone, most of the
crowd settled back for the
fireworks. Moonies, as always,

The "Greatest Show of the
Century" began with Sousa tunes
from the band and mortar bursts
over the reflecting pool. A
game-show announcer's voice
came over the PA system in a
deep bass, backed by elevator
Muzak. Promising a "true way to
celebrate the birth of America,"
shells and rockets burst in sharp
white flares, leading into a
continent-by -continent
international spectacular. Both
Moonies and Yippies were
_equally subdued, one from
patriotic God-fearing awe, the
other from acid- like color
explosions.
World
The forty minute firework
display offered some intriguing
combinations of description and
music. Asia's "ageless patience"
got Latin rhythms; Australia
swung to the tunes of Western
musicals; the Antarctic received
the support of a Verdi overture.
After the final round of shell
explosions, the 'mechanical voice
intoned,"America must build the
model of the ideal nation of God.
With that !done, the rest of the
world will follow America's
example and will build the,
Kingdom of God upon their
respective lands." At that point,
the show over and helicopter
searchlights flashing, people
sought their blankets and chairs
and complained about the slow
drive home. The blue-bannered
Moonies stood guard around the
stage area, red banners retrieved
the foreign flags from the
audience. Police marched out to
direct traffic, happy that not
even a shoving match had
occurred during the evening.
As people trudged over the
litter covering the Mall area (a
tremendous amount of litter
which, like the posters, would be
efficiently removed the next
day), the PA announcer
innocently called out the "Lost
Children" location. Parents
wondered how their children had
strayed into this mindless,
negative, anti-life guard, while
the Moonies quietly folded up
chairs and cleared the stage.
The end
Sun Myung Moon had blessed
the nation's capital, had taken
another step destined him since
he saw Jesus on a Korean hillside
at the age of sixteen. Sulfur
fumes and dense smoke drifted
toward the Capitol, chasing the
demons of the night and
signifying another battle won.
Busses loaded up for Baltimore
and New York, carrying tired
spectators back home for the end
of the weekend, Monday not far
away. Resting beyond the dying
orange flares, Lincoln shifted in
his chair, perhaps wanting to
raise a hand and wave slightly to
the end of the day.

Jazz invades M onumentalCity and knocks 'em dead
By MIKE GIULIANO
If you're from New York,
disappointment is inevitable.
Baltimore doesn't have nightclub
jazz, though guitarist Charlie
Byrd and vocalist Ethel Ennis
often appear at the Playboy Club
downtown. Attempts have been
made to bring small club jazz to
Baltimore, and all have been
failures. (The most recent effort,
Shakespeare's on Howard Street,
closed last spring. They had
offered nightclubbers an
alternative to disco; on some
nights the quartets outnumbered
the p-atrons. Things weren't
swinging.)
The nearest New York-type
club is probably the Cellar Door
in Georgetown; Muddy Waters,
John Abercrombie, Willie Dixon,
and Pat Martino, were only a few
of the big names who played the
Cellar Door this past summer;it's
worth the ride down.
Through Washingotn is a much
better town for jazz, you're most
likely stuck in Baltimore, and
there is live jazz in Baltimore.
The Left Bank Jazz Society
sponsors concerts every Sunday
from 5-9 p.m., in the Famous
Ballroom (1717 N. Charles St.)
The cost is $5.50 for the general
public. It is advisable to go in a
group; this is not for reasons of
safety, but because most Left
Bankers have been bringing their
own food, drinks, and friends to
the Ballroom for years. And
besides, you don't really want to
go by yourself, do you? For a
recorded schedule of upcoming
concerts and changes in concert
times, call 945-2266.
Morgan State University
(HiBen Rd. and Cold Spring
Lane) is holding a Black Music
Festival from Monday September
20, until Saturday the 25th. All
festival workshops and concerts

will be in Morgan's Murphy
Auditorium. A panel discussion
will be held at 10 a.m. and a
workshop at p.m. on each day of
the festival. Monday's discussion
and workshop will focus on
blues. Tuesday, gospel music will
be the topic, and there will be a
free concert at 7 p.m. with the
M.C.A. and Memorial Jubilee
choirs. Wednesday is rhythm and
blues day, with a free concert at
7 p.m.; scheduled to perform are
Rain, Hughes Production, Sound
xperience, and Manfield.
Thursday focuses on jazz. There
will be a concert at 7 p.m. Price
of admission is $3 and includes
refreshments. The performers are
Jack McLean, Dr. Simpkins,
Cosmic Brotherhood, John
Lamkin, Chain Reaction Carl
and Earl Grubbs. Friday: black
music and the humanities will be
the topic of discussion. A free
concert at 7 p.m. will feature
Steel Bank, Myca, and Black
Fungus. The final day of the
festival (Saturday, September 25)
sounds like the most promising.
The Left Bank Jazz Society will
lead a discussion at 10 a.m.; the 2
p.m. session is entitled
Reflections on Black Music .
There will be two performances
that night; general admission is
$5 for the 7 p.m. show, and
$5.50 for the 11 p.m. show. The
scheduled performers are Charles
Earland, Nationa with
Madhubuti, and Dizzy Gillespie.
I don't know how satisfying
this festival will be, but these
types of events need support,
because most area colleges have
no jazz concerts scheduled this
fall.
Hopkins has three scheduled
concerts in the next few weeks:
Freddie Hubbard will perform in
Shriver at 8 p.m. on September
23; ticket prices are $4.50 for

those with a Hopkins' ID, $5-.50
for others, and are available at
the Union Desk. Charlie Byrd ha5.`
a concert in Turner on October
24 from 6-8 p.m. Hank Levy and
the Towson State University Jazz
Ensemble will give a free concert
in Shriver on November 7 at 7:30
p.m.
For jazz on film you might
look into the Black Musical Film
Festival which started last
weekend and will continue this
weekend, and for the next eight
weekends. The Maryland
Commission for Black History
and Culture is showing the films
on Friday and Saturday evenings
(8 p.m.) at 12 West Madison
Street. Admission is $2. The
films are mostly 1930's shorts
with Duke Ellington and his
orchestra, and Billie Holiday.
Each evening's program will last
around two hours. For further
information call 566-5688.

Jazz trumpeter Freddie Hubbard appeared in Shriver Hall last night from 8:30 to 11:00
P.M. before a small crowd
of three hundred. The Presidential election debates occurring at the same time were blamed for the
light turnout. The
concert satisfied those who bothered to turnout, however.
After a short warmup by his group, Hubbard began the first set with his well known composition "Red
Clay." The
audience roared its approval. He followed this with material from his latest album, "Windjammer"
(Columbia). The
album contains little more than watered-down jazz aimed at the disco market. Ironically, the concert-goers
preferred
the pure jazz to the disco funk that was designed to appeal to their pedestrian tastes.
The concert confirmed the view that Hubbard's tale nts are going to waste. His group was competent--but
not much
more.T hey were ideally suited to the mediocre music being performed.
Freddie Hubbard figured prominently as a sideman in the avant garde jazz movement of the sixties.
Many critics
consider the sessions he did with the groups of Art Blakey, John Coltrane, and Ornette Coleman as the high
point of his
career. Since the early seventies, his music has deteriorated into the uninspired funk it is now.
If anyone wants to discover the true ability of this trumpeter, he should acquire the double LP
Freddie iftibbard
(Blue Note Re-Issue Series). It contains the best recordings of his creative period.

find it easier to live in apathetic luxury.
To date the efforts of NAACP fundraisers have been
whole-hearted and vigorous, but they have not resulted in
anything approaching strong public support. Many of the
campaign coordinators feel that the black churches are
carrying a disproportionate amount of the burden in the fight
to get needed funds.
For example, at the Johns Hopkins University, the attempt
by Dr. Wickwire and his staff to arouse the concern of
community members has not even begun to get off the
ground. The familiar chord of student indifference is struck
again.
Contributions for the NAACP emergency drive are being
solicited, as well as loans. More is needed, however. The
Office of the Chaplain has put out a call for volunteers who
would be able to speak in churches this Sunday morning.
This is a very special contribution which only the college
students can make. A reaffirmation of faith by the young
people for the work of the civil rights movement might serve
to turn the tide ma campiagn which is running out of time.
Student leaders have not responded to pleas for assistance
from the Chaplain's Office to help the NAACP. It was
reported that SC President Steve Ponchak was approached by
a staff member from the Office of the Chaplain. Mr. Ponchak
was said to offer little encouragement for a mobilization
effort of the studentry.
Ron Bialek, SC Treasurer,
was even less enthusiastic when asked by News-Letter staffers
whether or not the Student Council would help this cause.
President Steven Muller failed to supply needed leadership
in this area, not taking the time to make a short public
statement expressing support for the fundraising and for the
whole civil rights movement. Other affairs have their
importance, but this should have taken precedence.
This weekend Johns Hopkins students have the
opportunity to prove that there is a conscience on this
campus. The Office of the Chaplain not only needs speakers,
but office workers as well. Help save the NAACP It will be
worth everybody's while.

So maybe we all met in L.A,

but will anyone remember PattY
Hearst and Harrises years front

bound to be another spectacle

Living legends are fine, but
brand new ones are better.

do the show and get down, you

received 11 centuries off for
good behavior." Editorial replies
from senior citizen Emily Lutella
(Gilda Radner) are presented
often—"What's all this fuss I hear
about violins on television?
Classical music is fine on TV.- If
Dur kids just listen to their little
rock,and roll records all day, how
can they become cultured?"
Chase interrupts, `\Miss •Lutella,
that's violence on television. Not
violins, violence." "Oh. That's
different. Never mind."
Skits and scenes are often shot
away from the stage, exposing
the nakedness of TV technology
and allowing producer Lorne
Michaels more room to work
with. The security guards in the
,NBC building lobby are even
given lines occasionally: "Yeah,
.uh, Mr. Michaels, your party is
on the way up. By the way, the
show hasn't been very funny so
ifar tonight." Glancing at his
badge,"uh, 111275."
The acid test of any comedy is
laughter. Is it funny or not?
Often Saturday Night provokes,
rather than a belly laugh or even
a good chuckle, an appreciative
smile, like the reaction to a good
,painting or drama. While it is a
kind of entertainment Lily
To
has recently termed
"Sensi-humor", or
"docu-comedy", it is not new.
Gleason for example, in the
Honeymooners, got the same
reaction—people smiled at the
pathetic fat bus driver Ralph
Kramden as often as they howled
at his hilarious Laurel and Hardy
fueds with Ed
Norton. Carol Burnett often does
the same kind of comedy. The
brilliant impression of Joe
Cocker given by SN regular John
Belushi is so accurate that it is
not intrinsically funny, but it is
just surreal enough to be
outrageously
comical—Cocker/Belushi pouring
beer all over himself in a frenzied
spasm of passion.
A 'commercial' for Shimmer
merits a similar reaction—"It's a
floor wax!" "No, it's a dessert
topping!" A slick Chevy Chase
steps between the fighting
couple, "Wait a minute, kids,
new Shimmer is both!" Not quite
far-fetched enough to be
hysterical, yet sharply
satirical —again, no laugh, but a
smile. In this genre, regular Dan
Akroyd's impression of Carter is
not to be missed. It is one of the
most outstanding things I have
ever seen on TV. It is so
stingingly accurate (Akroyd
captures not only the accent, but
the flavor and spirit ofICattet's
rhetoric) it merits not even a
smile, but simply a look of
a
amazement.
If Saturday Night is not a
major step in television, or not
the greatest thing to come along
in video comedy in decades, it is
definitely superior programming.
It exploits to great advantage its
'live' status— mistakes become
jokes, the looseness of a live
show supports and creates
spontaneity, and so on. It is an
important synthesis of the new
;and the old in TV comedy. It can
only get better, and I look
forward to its maturation.

the flattery inherent in what was

strong undertow to the city's
development, a force which
served to carry the middle class
out of the historical center of

built suburbs.

Muhlenberg opposition in ootballer's first battle
Tomorrow afternoon, the
1976 Johns Hopkins football
team will open its regular season
schedule against MAC rival
Muhlenberg on the Mules home
turf in Allentown, Pennsylvania.
However, the contest will also
mark the end to something—that
grueling process known as the
pre-season. The indeterminate
number of miles run, the
incalculable number of jumping
jacks performed, the unending
number of hours spent in front
of the blocking dummies—the
rewards for these endeavors will
hopefully begin to be reaped in
tomorrow's game.
For most of the team, it all
began a month ago amidst a bevy
of new and familiar faces and a
mad scramble for starting berths
against Muhlenberg,. From that
roster, Head Coach Dennis Cox
and his assistants have
determined tomorrow's opening
lineup—one which they hope will
lead the Blue Jays to a successful
season.
On offense, sophomore Tom
Bender will line up behind the
center and call out the signals for
the second straight year. On
running plays he will be handing
the ball off to junior fullback
Ken Bess or one of his two
tailbacks—senior Brett Miles and
Junior Bob Desimone. When the

situation calls for an aerial
attack, Bender will look most
often to junior split end Dave
Emala or senior tight end Mike
Rhodey.
Providing protection on pass
plays and opening holes for
Blue Jay runners will be an
offense linethat makes up in
aggressiveness what it may lack in
experience. Center Rick Law,
guard Rick Broadhurst and
tackles Chuck Kennedy and
Millard Tydings are all freshmen
while the only veteran is junior
guard Bill McEnroe.
Key subs on offense will
include tailback Mike Jurgenson,
who performed impressively in

Women's Hockey

improved to the point where I
think they'll be ready for
tomorrow's game."
Little is known about the
opposition for tomorrow's game.
Muhlenberg will be opening its
season also and, like the Jays,
they are a young team.
According to Cox, the Mules
have a run oriented offense that
depends alot on the option play.
To stop them, the Blue Jays will
have to cut off the outside
option, which is never an easy
task.
As usual, the team to beat in
the MAC is Widener. However,
due to strange scheduling,
Hopkins will not play that team.
JHU will play the number two
team in the league, F and M,and
that game comes next week.
But that is not in the Coach's
mind at all. What he's been
working on is tomorrow's
opener. And he likes what he
sees.
"I was very pleased_ with our
practices all this week," the
Coach concluded. "We're
definitely ready for Saturday's
game."

A Day in the Life
By JOSEPH BALSAMO
George didn't have an
exceptionally heavy beard, but it
was heavy enough to cause a few
minor problems. It seems that
George had to shave every one
and a half days to avoid the
grubby look. This meant that if
George shaved on morning "one"
and then dared to shave on
morning "two," he would look
like he had just been in the
Crimean War. In other words,
while you are safely grubby
beneath your sheets, George is
overtly grubby in broad daylight
during a few days of the week,
no matter how he swings it. For
example, he tried waking up
every other day at 4:00 a.m. to
shave, but he decided that this
inconvenience was more of a
problem. George was troubled.
He lived in a world where first
impressions are lasting, and he
cared enough about his
appearance to not want to seem
as if he didn't care.
George was well aware that hi,;
interview was in tburteen days.
so he worked out a shaving
schedule which would result in
his face looking like a freshly
goomed lawn on that very
important day.
It worked well. George trotted
into the bathroom that morning
and was happy to see a good herd
ot nubs. The ritual began with a
few pulls on the face, then a look
at the eyes, and before George
knew it the first stroke was

struck. Cheeks first, then jowls,
and then the upper lip which
Goerge loved. George would
ponder the mysterious and
fleeting transition between red
lip and brown face, that man
could never define. Perhaps it
was because he was so deep in
thought that George slid past his
chin and sliced his jugular vein.
Anger infused in him and anyone
could understand why. Of all
days to nick himself, George
picked a bad one. But very soon
George realized that it was more
than a scratch he was dealing
with when he saw the pink
Noxzema stream run onto the
tiles. Then he realizedi he was
using a Gillette double-edged
safety razor, and soon told the
mirror, "It can't be anything
much." But he couldn't fool.
himself. Cold water and
isopropyl alcohol couldn't stop
the wound from oozing, and
things were getting out of hand.
It suddently occurred to George
that no razor is safe. He resented
the way in which Gillette sold a
women's razor under the
misleading name of "Lady
Gillette" simply by changing his
gun metal gray razor handle to a
pastel green, and then smacking a
cartoon butterfly on the
packaging of each one.
George allowed for the
possibility that what had just
happened might have been a
suicide attempt. He remembered
from the Abnormal Psychology

course that he had taken that
some men had a self-mutilation
and suicidal tendency, which was
to be present ever since the
emergence of amphibians on the
evolutionary scene, as witnessed
by the efforts of some frogs to
drown themselves. But George
knew this to be so much junk,
because his life was hard enough
to be interesting and he knew

neither a magazine nor a
News-Letter on the back of his
basin. He caught sight of the
Crest tube also. It is
understandable that George read
so quickly when it is realized that
this was the main bulk of his
outside reading. George had all

such as this one post a

cent of the judgment
Since plaintiffs in these
cases do have the right to collect
there is no reason to allow the
debtor to conceal his assets
during an appeal which may take
years.
Racism
If Claiborne County was not
located in the South, it might be
possible that the sordid tale of
intolerance and misunderstanding
would not have been known. The
South has had its sins bared
regularly for the rest of the
nation to sing about the
Southern man, but injustice
and immorality are not indi-

By D. H. WARREN
They'll tell you America has
come a long way.Through the red
scares, locking up
J apanese-Americans, Joseph
McCarthy, the violence of racism,
right down to Richard Nixon
they say the system works, and
by golly, you should be proud.
They'll also tell you that
Americans are good, decent
People, a moral, likeable lot.
They call the American working
man the finest, and also the best
taken care of. Even our
Paperboys make more than half
the people on this planet. For all
this, they say you should give
thanks.
The National Association for
the Advancement of Colored
People (NAACP) isn't giving
much thanks these days, or even
applauding the country to which,
for the last 70 years, they've
tried to bring justice. The
NAACP says they're running
scared, because the organization
has to come Lip with $1.5 million
by September 28 in order to
appeal a decision rendered in
Mississippi state court.
It sounds scary— (and it is).
Injustice comes to mind.(But are
legal justice and ethical justice in
this country necessarily
s Ynonymous?) Mississippi
completes the well-worn picture
You've painted in your head. The
Scenario that must come down:
Pat, illiterate rednecks donning
their hoods, putting nigrahs in
their place down South. South.
(They shoot easy riders, don't
they?)
Extremes
An accurate picture in this
case, as in most, lies somewhere
between the two extreme
versions of reality presented by
the adversaries. Merchants are
scrambling for dollahs on one
Side, the NAACP, their lives on
the other. The situation could be
called desperate, perhaps for
both parties involved; possibly
for ourselyks, as well.
the story is about a small
American town with a
Population of approximately
1 1,000, seventy-five per cent of
Whom are black. It is the City of
Port Gibson, in Claiborne
County, Mississippi.
Mississippi in 1966 was
beginning to feel the
repercussions of the 1965 Civil
Rights Act. Black citizens, aided
by Federal officials, began to
Push for equal treatment under
the law and the right to fully
Participate in the elective
Process. As with most • change,
there was resistance.
In Claiborne County, the local
chapter of the NAACP saw fit to
write a letter to the County
officials asking that the police
force, school board, and other
Public jobs he integrated. After
all, the town is three-quarters
black, with blacks having a voting
majority. Three months went by,
and "as public officials
sometimes do," no response was
given to the letter from the
NAACP. Another letter was sent,
this time with the added threat
of economic boycotts against
local white merchants. The

Association demanded that the
merchants hire black employees
and treat them fairly.
Dickson Pyles, attorney for
the plaintiffs in the case against
the NAACP, contends that the
Port Gibson businesses were
small, family affairs, and
therefore could not use outside
help. Emmet Burns, Director of
the Jackson NAACP, argues that
if this was so, why are these
places now hiring blacks? The
two sides tell different tales.
The boycott of the Port
Gibson merchants went on for
about a year. What happened
then is difficult to reconstruct.
The NAACP contends some
white merchants hired black
employees, prompting the end of
the boycott. Dickson Pyles says,
"It is difficult to determine, but
it seems they (the boycotters)
just got tired." He alleges some
merchants had black friends who
got the boycott ended for them.
This might be true, or it might
only be a story to add more
confirmation by circumstance to
the lawyer's case.
Shootings
In April 1969, the shooting of
a black man by a white
policeman rekindled the boycott,
bringing into focus the issue of
race. How and why Roosevelt
"Dusty" Jackson died is the
subject of contrasting opinions.
Emmet Burns tells us that
Jackson, one night in town,came
to the aid of a friend who was
drunk and about to be
incarcerated. Jackson asked the
policeman for permission to take
the man home. The officer
refused and threatened Jackson
with arrest. Later, "Dusty" was
shot at his home by the white
policeman. Charles Evers, mayor
of Fayette, Mississippi, claims
Jackson was shot with his hands
held.
The official police story says
that when the officer arrived to
arrest Jackson for interference
with justice, "Dusty" drew and
the trooper responded in
self-defense. The black man was
killed in the "scuffle."
At this point the stories really
begin to diverge.
Emmet Burns, who admits not
being in the city at that time,
says that the police told members

of the black community to wait
at the Baptist Church to be
informed about what had
happened to "Dusty" Jackson.
The townspeople were aware
something had happened, but
just what was still unclear. Bums
told the News-Letter that
sheriff's deputies fired into the
Church an hour later. Dickson
Pyles does not mention the
Church incident in his version of
the story, but does say that a
black man was shot by a white
police officer.
There is not a single article to
be found in the periodical
literature of the time about any
such shooting in Mississippi. No
record of anything like it could
be found in the files of the
Clarion-Ledger in Jackson,
Mississippi. An Associated Press
reporter, Ron Harrist, who was in
Port Gibson when the tragic
events of 1969 took place, was
unable to recall any act of
violence so outstanding as
pumping a Baptist Church full of
bullets.
Harrist reports that after the
shooting of "Dusty" Jackson,
Charles Evers, and state NAACP
President Aaron Henry organized
marches and demonstrations. A
curfew was imposed by the
county and state troopers were
brought in to enforce it. Harrist
recalls arrests being made for
curfew violations, but not for
acts of violence.
There was a large meeting at
the Baptist Church one night,
Harrist said, which he attended.
Rumors were going around that
the White were on the roof with
weapons, waiting for the blacks
to come out. Later, the whites
would circulate stories about
large amounts of guns found in
the Church.
Nobody, as far as Ron Harrist
knows, shot anybody that night.
In the wake of shooting, the
NAACP resumed their demands
for Black personnel in the Port
Gibson police department. When
this was tagain refused, the
boycott was reinstated, and
fortified by blacks opening
business cooperatives of their
own.
Dickson Pyles claims the
NAACP was able to keep the
boycott going by instituting a
"reign of terror" against those

blacks who would not cooperate.
In his eighty-four page opinion
on the case against the NAACP,
Judge George Haynes concluded
that such violence did occur. The
NAACP flatly denies the charges.
Ron Harrist syas he knew
nothing about a terrorizing
campaign by the NAACP. He had
observed spontaneous
confrontations between black
neighbors who fell on different
sides of the issue, but felt there
had been no organization,behind
any,of it.
Back in 1968, the state of
Mississippi passed a law against
secondary boycotts, admittedly
directed at the NAACP. With the
passage of the law , the
merchants of Port Gibson filed
suit against the • NAACP in
October 1969.
The Association received a
Federal injuntion to hold off the
suit, but several counter
injunctions and four years later
the case did come to trial. The
event lasted eight months. The
judge deliberated for three years.
The NAACP was found in
violation of not only the 1968
state law prohibiting secondary
boycotts, but also statutes
concerning monopolies and
trusts, Mississippi common law
for "interfering with a business
relationship," and guilty of
conspiracy for those things.
Dickson Pyles said that all of
the defendants took the stand
and admitted that they were
boycotting the merchants in
order to have their demands with
the government met. To Pyles, it
was a "classic secondary
boycott." Dickson Pyles is a
lawyer who has built his
reputation from his handling of
labor and civil rights cases. In the
1950's, Pyles had his office
bombed because of his
association with a civil rights
case. Dickson Pyles was hired by
the merchants because of his
extensive knowledge of boycotts.
The sum of $1.2 million was
arrived at by trying to determine
what might have happened to the
businesses if the boycott had
never occurred. Dr. Paul T.
Oliver, Mississippi University
economist, projected a trend line
to ascertain the extent of this
economic possibility. Dickson
Pyles said,"It took us two weeks

The land of the Yippies. Black

band and dope smoking rather

Rah rah
The interplay between the

an instant replay of high-school
football. Visitors rooting for the
opposing team made more noise
and sarcastic comments, while
the strength of home rooters
drowned them out at key
moments. Tying both sides
together was the aura of a loser.
For the Yippies (again not a
true claim to the title), their
members came for a one-shot
deal of getting high and being
crazy in front of a lot of people.

The Moonies uniformly had a

Back in the crowd, spectators

With Moon gone, most of the

The "Greatest Show of the
Century" began with Sousa tunes
from the band and mortar bursts
over the reflecting pool. A
game-show announcer's voice
came over the PA system in a
deep bass, backed by elevator
Muzak. Promising a "true way to
celebrate the birth of America,"
shells and rockets burst in sharp
white flares, leading into a
continent-by -continent
international spectacular. Both
Moonies and Yippies were
_equally subdued, one from
patriotic God-fearing awe, the
other from acid- like color
explosions.
World
The forty minute firework
display offered some intriguing
combinations of description and
music. Asia's "ageless patience"
got Latin rhythms; Australia
swung to the tunes of Western
musicals; the Antarctic received
the support of a Verdi overture.
After the final round of shell
explosions, the 'mechanical voice
intoned,"America must build the
model of the ideal nation of God.
With that !done, the rest of the
world will follow America's
example and will build the,
Kingdom of God upon their
respective lands." At that point,
the show over and helicopter
searchlights flashing, people
sought their blankets and chairs
and complained about the slow
drive home. The blue-bannered
Moonies stood guard around the
stage area, red banners retrieved
the foreign flags from the
audience. Police marched out to
direct traffic, happy that not
even a shoving match had
occurred during the evening.
As people trudged over the
litter covering the Mall area (a
tremendous amount of litter
which, like the posters, would be
efficiently removed the next
day), the PA announcer
innocently called out the "Lost
Children" location. Parents
wondered how their children had
strayed into this mindless,
negative, anti-life guard, while
the Moonies quietly folded up
chairs and cleared the stage.
The end
Sun Myung Moon had blessed
the nation's capital, had taken
another step destined him since
he saw Jesus on a Korean hillside
at the age of sixteen. Sulfur
fumes and dense smoke drifted
toward the Capitol, chasing the
demons of the night and
signifying another battle won.
Busses loaded up for Baltimore
and New York, carrying tired
spectators back home for the end
of the weekend, Monday not far
away. Resting beyond the dying
orange flares, Lincoln shifted in
his chair, perhaps wanting to
raise a hand and wave slightly to
the end of the day.

If you're from New York,
disappointment is inevitable.
Baltimore doesn't have nightclub
jazz, though guitarist Charlie
Byrd and vocalist Ethel Ennis
often appear at the Playboy Club
downtown. Attempts have been
made to bring small club jazz to
Baltimore, and all have been
failures. (The most recent effort,
Shakespeare's on Howard Street,
closed last spring. They had
offered nightclubbers an
alternative to disco; on some
nights the quartets outnumbered
the p-atrons. Things weren't
swinging.)
The nearest New York-type

and Pat Martino, were only a few
of the big names who played the
Cellar Door this past summer;it's

Through Washingotn is a much

Jazz trumpeter Freddie Hubbard appeared in Shriver Hall last night from 8:30 to 11:00
P.M. before a small crowd
of three hundred. The Presidential election debates occurring at the same time were blamed for the
light turnout. The
concert satisfied those who bothered to turnout, however.
After a short warmup by his group, Hubbard began the first set with his well known composition "Red
Clay." The
audience roared its approval. He followed this with material from his latest album, "Windjammer"
(Columbia). The
album contains little more than watered-down jazz aimed at the disco market. Ironically, the concert-goers
preferred
the pure jazz to the disco funk that was designed to appeal to their pedestrian tastes.
The concert confirmed the view that Hubbard's tale nts are going to waste. His group was competent--but
not much
more.T hey were ideally suited to the mediocre music being performed.
Freddie Hubbard figured prominently as a sideman in the avant garde jazz movement of the sixties.
Many critics
consider the sessions he did with the groups of Art Blakey, John Coltrane, and Ornette Coleman as the high
point of his
career. Since the early seventies, his music has deteriorated into the uninspired funk it is now.
If anyone wants to discover the true ability of this trumpeter, he should acquire the double LP
Freddie iftibbard
(Blue Note Re-Issue Series). It contains the best recordings of his creative period.

find it easier to live in apathetic luxury.
To date the efforts of NAACP fundraisers have been
whole-hearted and vigorous, but they have not resulted in
anything approaching strong public support. Many of the
campaign coordinators feel that the black churches are
carrying a disproportionate amount of the burden in the fight
to get needed funds.
For example, at the Johns Hopkins University, the attempt
by Dr. Wickwire and his staff to arouse the concern of
community members has not even begun to get off the
ground. The familiar chord of student indifference is struck
again.
Contributions for the NAACP emergency drive are being
solicited, as well as loans. More is needed, however. The
Office of the Chaplain has put out a call for volunteers who
would be able to speak in churches this Sunday morning.
This is a very special contribution which only the college
students can make. A reaffirmation of faith by the young
people for the work of the civil rights movement might serve
to turn the tide ma campiagn which is running out of time.
Student leaders have not responded to pleas for assistance
from the Chaplain's Office to help the NAACP. It was
reported that SC President Steve Ponchak was approached by
a staff member from the Office of the Chaplain. Mr. Ponchak
was said to offer little encouragement for a mobilization
effort of the studentry.
Ron Bialek, SC Treasurer,
was even less enthusiastic when asked by News-Letter staffers
whether or not the Student Council would help this cause.
President Steven Muller failed to supply needed leadership
in this area, not taking the time to make a short public
statement expressing support for the fundraising and for the
whole civil rights movement. Other affairs have their
importance, but this should have taken precedence.
This weekend Johns Hopkins students have the
opportunity to prove that there is a conscience on this
campus. The Office of the Chaplain not only needs speakers,
but office workers as well. Help save the NAACP It will be
worth everybody's while.

Nixon was no longer a threat tc
society and his incarceration
would have merely served as a

transcended the prison walls; we
all think of him as the worst type
of criminal anyway.
Now think about Patty Hearst.
Does anyone possibly believe
that she's a menace to the United
States and that prison will
"reform" her? Remember, she
didn't ask to join the SLA, she
was kidnapped, and had a ream
of extenuatin circumstances to
present to the jury. Her guilt was
far less established than Nixon's.
Sure, she was photographed
wielding a gun at that bank
robbery, but just the fact that
she was kidnapped ought to
nullify much of her apparent
guilt. And after all, anyone
would be a fugitive knowing that
the biased hands of the law were
on their heads.
Big Deal
But Patty wasn't just any
kidnapping victim. She was a
Hearst, member of a filthy rich
newspaper family, open to all
sorts of media invasion. She was
in the news every day. The
enviable prey of a discredited
FBI trying to regain its stature in
the heartland of the country. All
year long, amateur lawyers and
"criminals in their coats and ties"
debated her case back and forth,
sipping mornina coffee, pleased

They didn't realize that for Patty

Raw Deal
Although they didn't receive
half the publicity that PattY
commanded, Bill and EmilY
Harris got a raw deal too, because
they refused to "play ball with
the law." Bill Harris told the
judge,"We aren't being convicted
because we're a threat to society,
but because society is afraid of
our ideas." The Harrises werent
convicted of a single violent
crime but were still given longel
sentences than many rapists and
murderers. Amazed? Check out
the court docket each day in 711e
Sun. They were put away for
their political beliefs, not thett
every day mundane crimes. The
judge had too much at stake not
to nail them.
So maybe we all met in L.A,
when the Hurricane was released
but will anyone remember PattY
Hearst and Harrises years front
now? Don't count on it, there's
bound to be another spectacle
clogging the waves of the media.
Living legends are fine, but
brand new ones are better.

received 11 centuries off for
good behavior." Editorial replies
from senior citizen Emily Lutella
(Gilda Radner) are presented
often—"What's all this fuss I hear
about violins on television?
Classical music is fine on TV.- If
Dur kids just listen to their little
rock,and roll records all day, how
can they become cultured?"
Chase interrupts, `\Miss •Lutella,
that's violence on television. Not
violins, violence." "Oh. That's
different. Never mind."
Skits and scenes are often shot
away from the stage, exposing
the nakedness of TV technology
and allowing producer Lorne
Michaels more room to work
with. The security guards in the
,NBC building lobby are even
given lines occasionally: "Yeah,
.uh, Mr. Michaels, your party is
on the way up. By the way, the
show hasn't been very funny so
ifar tonight." Glancing at his
badge,"uh, 111275."
The acid test of any comedy is
laughter. Is it funny or not?
Often Saturday Night provokes,
rather than a belly laugh or even
a good chuckle, an appreciative
smile, like the reaction to a good
,painting or drama. While it is a
kind of entertainment Lily
To
has recently termed
"Sensi-humor", or
"docu-comedy", it is not new.
Gleason for example, in the
Honeymooners, got the same
reaction—people smiled at the
pathetic fat bus driver Ralph
Kramden as often as they howled
at his hilarious Laurel and Hardy
fueds with Ed
Norton. Carol Burnett often does
the same kind of comedy. The
brilliant impression of Joe
Cocker given by SN regular John
Belushi is so accurate that it is
not intrinsically funny, but it is
just surreal enough to be
outrageously
comical—Cocker/Belushi pouring
beer all over himself in a frenzied
spasm of passion.
A 'commercial' for Shimmer
merits a similar reaction—"It's a
floor wax!" "No, it's a dessert
topping!" A slick Chevy Chase
steps between the fighting
couple, "Wait a minute, kids,
new Shimmer is both!" Not quite
far-fetched enough to be
hysterical, yet sharply
satirical —again, no laugh, but a
smile. In this genre, regular Dan
Akroyd's impression of Carter is
not to be missed. It is one of the
most outstanding things I have
ever seen on TV. It is so
stingingly accurate (Akroyd
captures not only the accent, but
the flavor and spirit ofICattet's
rhetoric) it merits not even a
smile, but simply a look of
a
amazement.
If Saturday Night is not a
major step in television, or not
the greatest thing to come along
in video comedy in decades, it is
definitely superior programming.
It exploits to great advantage its
'live' status— mistakes become
jokes, the looseness of a live
show supports and creates
spontaneity, and so on. It is an
important synthesis of the new
;and the old in TV comedy. It can
only get better, and I look
forward to its maturation.

History of Charles Village written by Jacques Kelly
By BOB BUCHANAN
The history of one of the
City's oldest and most unique
neighborhoods is artfully
depicted in Jacques Steward
Kelly's book,Peabody Heights to
Charles Village, a recently
released document printed with
financial assistance from the
Equitable Trust Bank.
The story is of the area of the
northern city now formed by the
residences along Charles,
Guilford, Maryland, Abel, Calvert
and St. Paul streets and avenues,
and bordered on the north and
south by 25th and 33rd streets.
Kelly's work stresses the flavor of
enthusiasm which was an
essential ingredient to the sudden
blossoming of the community
containing some of Baltimore's
most wealthy inhabitants at the
turn of the century.
The promoters of the
residential endeavor had much
more on their minds than merely
the flattery inherent in what was
then the northern countryside of
Baltimore. Kelly notes that since
the period immediately preceding
the Civil War, there had been a
strong undertow to the city's
development, a force which
served to carry the middle class
out of the historical center of
Baltimore and toward the newly
built suburbs.

Go Brett Go!

Muhlenberg opposition in ootballer's first battle
Tomorrow afternoon, the
1976 Johns Hopkins football
team will open its regular season
schedule against MAC rival
Muhlenberg on the Mules home
turf in Allentown, Pennsylvania.
However, the contest will also
mark the end to something—that
grueling process known as the
pre-season. The indeterminate
number of miles run, the
incalculable number of jumping
jacks performed, the unending
number of hours spent in front
of the blocking dummies—the
rewards for these endeavors will
hopefully begin to be reaped in
tomorrow's game.
For most of the team, it all
began a month ago amidst a bevy
of new and familiar faces and a
mad scramble for starting berths
against Muhlenberg,. From that
roster, Head Coach Dennis Cox
and his assistants have
determined tomorrow's opening
lineup—one which they hope will
lead the Blue Jays to a successful
season.
On offense, sophomore Tom
Bender will line up behind the
center and call out the signals for
the second straight year. On
running plays he will be handing
the ball off to junior fullback
Ken Bess or one of his two
tailbacks—senior Brett Miles and
Junior Bob Desimone. When the

situation calls for an aerial
attack, Bender will look most
often to junior split end Dave
Emala or senior tight end Mike
Rhodey.
Providing protection on pass
plays and opening holes for
Blue Jay runners will be an
offense linethat makes up in
aggressiveness what it may lack in
experience. Center Rick Law,
guard Rick Broadhurst and
tackles Chuck Kennedy and
Millard Tydings are all freshmen
while the only veteran is junior
guard Bill McEnroe.
Key subs on offense will
include tailback Mike Jurgenson,
who performed impressively in

Women's Hockey

improved to the point where I
think they'll be ready for
tomorrow's game."
Little is known about the
opposition for tomorrow's game.
Muhlenberg will be opening its
season also and, like the Jays,
they are a young team.
According to Cox, the Mules
have a run oriented offense that
depends alot on the option play.
To stop them, the Blue Jays will
have to cut off the outside
option, which is never an easy
task.
As usual, the team to beat in
the MAC is Widener. However,
due to strange scheduling,
Hopkins will not play that team.
JHU will play the number two
team in the league, F and M,and
that game comes next week.
But that is not in the Coach's
mind at all. What he's been
working on is tomorrow's
opener. And he likes what he
sees.
"I was very pleased_ with our
practices all this week," the
Coach concluded. "We're
definitely ready for Saturday's
game."

A far more experienced
women's field hockey squad will
take to the field this afternoon
When the Lady Jays open their
third season of intercollegiate
play.
In women's field hockey,
games are divided into two
thirty-five minute halves. Each
Player must be in excellent
shape, for there are no
substitutions allowed during the
contest—player changes may only
be made at halftime or in the
event of an injury.
Each team fields eleven
Players. Traditionally, the lineup
consisted of five forwards, three
halfbacks, two fullbacks and a
goalie. Although some schools
have altered this formation in
past years, JHU will maintain this
allignment.
"I think that this will work
Well for us," Mrs. Morse
explained. "We have enough
forwards to make this a
successful set-up."

remain, the Coach has
determined much of her starting

A Day in the Life
By JOSEPH BALSAMO
George didn't have an
exceptionally heavy beard, but it
was heavy enough to cause a few
minor problems. It seems that
George had to shave every one
and a half days to avoid the
grubby look. This meant that if
George shaved on morning "one"
and then dared to shave on
morning "two," he would look
like he had just been in the
Crimean War. In other words,
while you are safely grubby
beneath your sheets, George is
overtly grubby in broad daylight
during a few days of the week,
no matter how he swings it. For
example, he tried waking up
every other day at 4:00 a.m. to
shave, but he decided that this
inconvenience was more of a
problem. George was troubled.
He lived in a world where first
impressions are lasting, and he
cared enough about his
appearance to not want to seem
as if he didn't care.
George was well aware that hi,;

so he worked out a shaving

his face looking like a freshly
goomed lawn on that very
important day.

and was happy to see a good herd
